transcription.text: [Music]
The patterns by the Gang of Four is very famous and also outside of the field of developing
you have patterns. So if I want to need a Celtic pillow, I wouldn't know where to start.
So first I Google and then I get this kind of stuff. I'm not sure what it is. It looks like
brain fog codes, but probably it tells me how to need a pillow.
So what is a pattern? A pattern is a reusable solution for common occurring problems that you can apply.
It's not some boilerplate piece of code that you just copy paste and you don't with it.
You apply it to your own cortex, but you try to reuse it.
You try to see when does it make sense, when does it make sense?
And in the pattern description, the pattern language, we mentioned when is the good problem
to apply this pattern, when you shouldn't do it, and if you're applying it, what are the considerations?
And of course, some code examples.
Yeah, Microsoft guys with their Azure Cloud, they also release all kinds of patterns.
So in all kinds of software engineering fields, you have this pattern system.
So probably the next version of these slides will have the blockchain pattern in here as well.
So when looking at the patterns, we discover three areas.
We have data patterns, transaction of value patterns, and we have action and control patterns.
Maybe there are much more different categories, but these are the three distinctions that we came up with.
And I'm going to mention six examples from these sets.
Actually this morning, we've seen the fan-in and fan-out pattern from the block apps demo.
We've seen the escrow example earlier.
So already during this day, you have witnessed a couple of patterns without even realizing it.
So for each of these patterns, we'll mention, well, of course, the name of it,
a definition of the problem.
So when can you apply this pattern?
And then if you're going to apply it, what kind of context, what kind of considerations,
what kind of constraints are there to be assured of, followed by an actual solution of this pattern,
and a couple examples out of all the code that is publicly available on GitHub already.
And you see these patterns are quite often related to each other.
So if you apply it to each other, you might consider it as a non-pattern.
You might consider it as a non-pattern.
You might consider it as a non-pattern.
Or even use them in combination of each other.
So first of all, the data patterns, two examples.
The first one is the name registry.
You need this if you're looking for a human readable name for its area address.
And you might need this human readable name because you want to display it in your user interface.
Maybe you have a wallet application and you want to show the person that you're transferring something to.
Or you have a game and you want to show the nickname of the person that was just winning your contest.
Or because your depth consists of a cluster of contracts that are related with each other,
you want to make a reference from one contract to the other.
But this relationship is a non-appront.
So you want to refer to the other contract by name instead of hard coding address in your contracts.
And of course that's the advantage.
That if you update the name registry, you can also update the code of your code constructs.
And you can even apply heroic patterns here where you get some kind of zip domain registry.
You can point a registry for domain and then for every household within an area that would be a nodal reference
to another name registry for the individual people living there.
Of course, there's some issues with this.
You have the traditional kind of problems that you're also seeing in the DNS name registry.
So you have this name squatting potential.
What happens if you lose your key? Is this name going to be lost?
And we're going to expire it.
Maybe you can outbid somebody else. So there's all these complex things to think of as well.
So a solution here is to create a contract registry.
And this could either be a global one that you use in all your Ethereum applications
or it could be one specific for your context or for your application.
And it has a reference from a name to an address. It's just a big hash map.
It just looks in the contract storage for the given name.
What is the address that is associated with it? And then it returns the address.
And you can extend this by giving a reverse look up.
So you can query it for an address and then you can see what is the name that belongs to this address.
And a good example here is the name rack contracts that is actually implemented by Gavin.
I think it's in the depth bin getter projects in the Ethereum repository.
And here you have the name register implementation.
So you can take a look at this and see how Gavin does it.
So the second data pattern is this data feed.
Smart contracts, they cannot reach out to the real world.
You cannot make HTTP call and see what the website returns as a value.
You cannot directly connect the camera to it so you can make a picture.
So you need to actually feed the data to your contracts to get some kind of value out of it.
So what if if you're making an application that needs to know the weather for a certain area
or it needs to know an exchange rate so you can exchange your ether for Bitcoin
or your Pfizer-Prouser.
And yeah, there's this limitation of this theorem virtual machine where because it's deterministic
you cannot look outside and fetch data into the blockchain by itself.
So what you need to do, you actually need to feed this data into Ethereum onto the blockchain.
And then once it is there, every other application on the Ethereum blockchain can actually use it.
And use the fashion that you really didn't think of yourself before.
So typically you'll need an automated process, some kind of demon that frequently publishes
updates to this data feed.
So maybe once every day what the weather was or what exchange rate was or more frequent
or less frequent depending on your usage.
And of course you can publish this as a free service but you can also ask for a fee if people
are getting the data out of this data feed.
So of course there's some cost associating with sapling up such a process that keeps updating,
keeps pushing data to the Ethereum contracts.
At least you need to pay the guess and also some kind of hosting fee.
So you could actually charge every contract that is using this and that could be a viable revenue
model for data feeds.
Yeah, I've given you these examples already.
And a much more advanced example is the BTC relay contracts where it's actually storing
blocks and transactions from the Bitcoin onto Ethereum.
So then you can use this on the Ethereum blockchain as well.
And as an example here we have the price feed example from Nick Dodson.
I think he's also here, I might be presenting later this week.
So here they're pushing free at currency prices on the blockchain and then you can use that
for some kind of trade, some set up some kind of escrow without having to rely on the exchange
rate of Ether itself.
So looking at these transaction and value related patterns, two examples.
The asset token, we have seen that in Peter's presentation.
So you need to have some kind of representation from either virtual or physical assets on the
blockchain so you can, for crowdfunding purposes, so you can sell it or maybe so you can lease
your car or you can trade it with somebody else or you can track it for auditing purposes.
And typically these assets are equal in kind so you can enumerate them and you can have
multiple of them.
And for this, if you use a standard interface and there's the meta currency API description
here in Wicke, if you use the same kind of interface for this, then you can use all kinds of different
wallets and exchanges to track your sub currency, to track your assets without the wallet itself
having to specifically support you.
So what you do, you create a contract and based on your track per account, how much of these
assets they have in the contract storage.
And then you set up maybe at least two functions, one to transfer these assets from one account
to your account and one to return the balance of one of these account holders in there.
And if you have this, you can use this to create crowdfunding tokens, set up IOU constructions,
track fiat currencies, US dollars, euros, whatever, or even as Digix is doing, keep track of gold
certificates on the blockchain.
And here as an example is from Flocket, they are crowdfunding contracts, they are also using
this pattern.
So they're doing some kind of crowdfunding, probably we'll hear more about this later on,
but you can transfer these tokens to somebody else and you can also see what your balance is.
Another one of these value and transaction related patterns is the exchange or market.
So you have one of these assets tokens, so that's actually from the previous example,
and you want to sell it, buy it, exchange it for something else.
So you can set up an exchange on the blockchain itself.
You don't need any kind of central websites that will do this exchange for you and then
lose your money and run away with it, but you can do all of this on the blockchain.
And typically both the assets for a one-on-one exchange will be one of these assets on the blockchain,
or one of the two could be just the eater currency itself, but I guess that's less common.
And then of course the trick is how are you going to do this settlement if you have a huge ledger?
Maybe it's very good to have the user indicate which is the winning pair and have it match that way,
or you need some kind of external trigger that will be called to do the matching and the settlement payouts.
But that's potentially expensive.
So what you need to do, you need to have a contract, you need to keep track of the bids or the buy orders,
keep track of all the asks or the sell orders, and have some kind of matching mechanism,
and once the bid and ask is matched, you swap the assets from both account holders to the other one.
An example of this is Vitalix Cyberdie Market.
It's written in a serpent instead of Solidity, so it's a good homework exercise to try to convert that from serpent to Solidity.
And another example is the EtherX exchange.
So here an example from a Cyberdyne, you see there's a buy function, there's a sell function,
but you can use this market, this exchange, to exchange all kinds of assets that have the same interface
without having to upfront implement support for this in your contracts.
So the third and final group that we have seen are these action-related patterns.
Event log, so it's a feature of the EVM itself, you can emit events and they will be persisted on the blockchain,
and you can use them to track states or to track when some kind of action happens, and have the outside respond to it.
There's a limitation though with the EVM, from one contract you cannot inspect the event log of itself or of another contract.
So you can only use this data from the outside, but this makes it ideal for user interface purposes,
or if you have some kind of watchdog process that is looking at these event logs and acts upon them.
So, yes, just a single line of Solidity code to emit an event if an action happens, and then you have a listening process
or a watching process and you use interface that will update its state accordingly.
So examples of this, if a buy order took place, pay one update, your crowdfunding website, if you just lease your car key to somebody else,
you need to change the code, the public key on the log system, if an account is registered, maybe some other event takes place.
So a good example here is the Wi-funds, again from Nick Dotson, the Wi-fund crowdfunding contracts.
So yes, these events are emitted when a new campaign is created, when a contribution is made, when a payout happens,
and even when a refund happens.
Maybe he doesn't even use these kind of events himself, but by just sharing them, you allow orders to consume them
and create all kinds of user interface and interactions with them that you didn't think of yourself.
So, yeah, there's a bit of an issue with Ethereum, there's no alarm upcode.
You cannot trigger some kind of future event to happen automatically, so every action in a contract needs to be triggered by a transaction
that is eventually being sent from a user.
So what if something needs to happen in the future?
How are you going to make sure that this happens?
An example of this is if you need some kind of, I don't know, expiration of your lottery ticket, doing frequent dividend payouts,
other kinds of cleanups, how are you going to make sure that this will happen?
So the solution here is to reward the caller for actually triggering this mechanism.
So you create a function, anybody can trigger this, but once they do this, they get rewarded for doing so,
and that way you hope, of course, you cannot guarantee that somebody will do it, but they have a strong economic incentive
for triggering this method and making sure that it will be called.
So an example here from Gefin's casino contract is this recycle method, which anybody can trigger,
and if there's some kind of expiration event, the person that was triggering this gets rewarded with half a percent of the difference.
So it makes sense there.
So combining these things together, you can come up with all kinds of use cases.
So say you have a betting website where you want to allow your users to bet on soccer scores,
you would use a name registry to keep track of the different user names, so you can have a top scoring list,
how will fame on your side or on your depth.
You need some kind of data feed to know which soccer events happened and what scoring was there.
Event lock, so if somebody takes a bet or if you want to update, again, your website or your depth accordingly,
so you use event lock to get the outputs from that.
So whether you see with such a system, you're combining multiple of these patterns together.
Again, from market, if you have some kind of manufacturing site and you do some kind of internal research optimization,
you can try to centralize this, but you can also think about, can we do this on the blockchain,
using asset token to indicate resources, having an exchange contract where people can bid and ask for resources,
and then, of course, having some kind of incentivized trigger for making sure that frequent updates, such as market settlements happen.
Another example is if you want to have your depth interact with real hardware.
So in this case, it's a smart meter in my utility cluster that I connect with my Ethereum Raspberry Pi.
I get data out of it, but how do you know that this device belongs to me?
So I need some kind of notary data pattern that makes this association.
I have this data feed, so for every energy consumption update, a contract is updated with my data usage,
and if I want to display this in my depth, I need to emit event locks using the event lock pattern.
So what's next?
For you guys, take a look at existing code in GitHub, existing contracts, study them,
and see what kind of common patterns do you see are used and can be used for yourself.
And also, we're trying as a community effort to get this stack overflow, stack exchange site set up for Ethereum.
So if you go to Area 31 on the stack exchange, please vote for it.
As of this morning, I think we were at almost 70%.
So a couple more votes, and we have a community site for all kinds of Q&A, all kinds of discussions
around best practices about patterns, sharing code, sharing knowledge with each other,
and this will be a great place to exchange Ethereum or depth patterns as well.
Thank you guys.
